title: Manhattan: Union Square.

folder: Union Square & 4th Avenue & Between 15th and 17th Streets & Celebration of the 100th Anniversary of founding of Union Square., Manhattan, NY
text:
The Celebration of the 100th Anniversary of the founding of Union Square, at 4th Avenue, between 15th and 17th Streets, New York City, by prominent State, Civic and Local Organizations.

From,
A.H. Scrap Book of the Revolution. No date.

"Union Square located at the convergence of several Streets, where 4th Avenue and the old Bowery Road met, made it necessary to have there a Common. At times it was used as a Potter's Field, much of it's area being covered with rude shanties, but surrounded by fine mansions. It remained the Belgrade of Manhattan until about 1845, when homes were moved farther North."

P.40. King's Handbook of New York.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 4th Avenue - Between 15th and 17th Streets - Celebration of the 100th Anniversary of founding of Union Square.

folder: Union Square (West) & Between 16th and 17th Streets., Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square West, north from and including 16th Street, to and including 17th Streets. The view also shows 17th Street, north side, west from and including Broadway. Also shown is 16th Street, south side, at, adjoining and west of Union Square West.

About 1874.

Brown Brothers.

folder: Union Square (East) & Between 16th and 17th Streets., Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square East, north from but not including 16th Street, to and including 17th Street. Fourth Ave., is shown north from, and including 17th Street (said Ave., being a continuation of Union Square East). Also seen is 17th Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Fourth Ave.

About 1913.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 16th and 17th Streets.
World War Commission. French. May 1917. Lafayette Statue, Union Square

folder: Union Square & [Union Square Park.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square; A view northward showing across the Park a row of buildings on the north side of East 17th Street between Broadway (left) and Fourth Ave. (right). These latter thoroughfares when forming the boundaries of the Square are known as Union Square West and Union Square East respectively. The tower of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. Building appears in the background.

About 1922.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - [Union Square Park.]

folder: Union Square (East) & [36-44, 46-48 Union Square] & Between 16th and 17th Streets., Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
36-44 and 46-8 Union Square East, from 16th to 17th Streets, showing Fourth Avenue to 19th Street. The five old residences were built about 1850; the Westmoreland apartment house was built around 1877 as a hotel. William Lloyd Garrison, the great Anti-Slavery agitator, died there; he is commemorated by a tablet on the building. This description is being written by a man who was born there.
The Westmoreland, together with 44 Union Square adjoining, is about to be demolished for the new Tammany Hall building.
January 23, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Union Square East, from 16th to 17th Streets, showing 36-42 Union Square and the clearing on the corner of 17th Street.
June 26, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - [36-44, 46-48 Union Square] - Between 16th and 17th Streets.

folder: Union Square (West) & Between 16th and 17th Streets., Manhattan, NY
text:
31-41 Union Square West, from 16th to 17th Streets, seen from Fourth Avenue and 17th Street. The tall building on the N.W. corner of 16th Street is the Bank of the Metropolis, erected between 1902 and 1910 on the site of the old house which the same bank had occupied during its first six years, 1871-77. The Union Square Building, 33 Union Square West, was built around 1895, and originally called the Decker Building. The Hartford Building, 41 Union Square, on the S.W. corner of 17th Street, was also built about the same time. In 1900 old 31 Union Square was occupied by Brentano's, 33 Union Square (the Decker Building) by Fischer Pianos, and 35 by G. Schirmer, music publisher.

July 7, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (West) - Between 16th and 17th Streets.

folder: Union Square (West) & Between 14th and 17th Streets (East)., Manhattan, NY
text:
1 to 41 Union Square West, west side, north from East 14th (left) to East 17th (right) Streets, showing buildings which line this side of the street, opposite the Park, as seen westward from the Consolidated Edison Co. Building. The vacant lot shown at the S.W. corner of East 16th Street was caused by the demolition of Nos. 21 to 29 Union Square West and 20 and 22 East 16th Street. The horizon formed in the background is the New Jersey Palisades.

March 27, 1929.

New York Edison Company.

folder: Union Square (East) & Between 14th and 15th Streets., Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square East, from 14th to 15th Streets, inclusive, from an elevation, showing the 8-10-12 Union Square, old residences, and the Hotel America at 104 East 15th Street, being remodeled for S. Klein's expending business. This is the newer Hotel America; the building was taken over from the Hotel Jefferson (originally Hotel Dam, built around 1885). The old Union Square Hotel, built in the late 70's, occupies the site of 14-16-18 Union Square, on the S.E. corner of 15th Street. The Union Square Savings Bank on the N.W. corner was erected between 1902 and 1910.
August 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 14th and 15th Streets.

folder: Union Square (East) & Between 15th and 16th Streets., Manhattan, NY
text:
Neg. No. 223 =

(1)
24, 26-8, and 30 Union Square, between 15th and 16th Streets, occupied by the Polish daily Novy Swiat ("The New World"), The Daily Worker (organ of the Communist Party), and the radical Jewish Freiheit ("Freedom"). These buildings, except possibly 24, are business buildings built on the site of the original houses, probably around 1880. They may be located on the Edison Company's photograph of Union Square in 1893. The Daily Worker has only moved in since 1928. All these buildings will, before 1933, be taken over and remodelled by S. Klein as a store for higher-priced dresses. At the time of this picture, the Co-operative Cafeteria pictured here was the regular hangout of the Communist organizers, much as Luchow's Restaurant on 14th Street used to be (and still is) frequented by district leaders from mammany Hall. August 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Neg. No. 223 a+b

(2)
The same, earlier the same year.
February 20, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 15th and 16th Streets.

folder: Union Square (East) & Between 15th and 16th Streets., Manhattan, NY
text:
20-34 Union Square East, from 15th to 16th Streets, with a portion of the park (which was drastically remodelled, 1929-30) in the foreground. The Union Square Savings Bank, 20-22 Union Square on the 15th Street corner, was erected between 1902 and 1910. The 11-story Reliance Building was also erected at the same time, replacing an old 4-story house. 34 Union Square on the corner of 16th Street, was built prior to 1890.
Old 24, 26-8, and 30 have been taken over since 1930 and remodelled by S. Klein; another story has been added to 24. See 1930 views of these three buildings.

P. L. Sperr.
February 24, 1933.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 15th and 16th Streets.

text:
Strikes and Demonstrations: An Ex-service orator addressing a group at the S.W. corner of Union Square. Photographer is viewing northeastward across the Park to show the building outline on Union Square East, between East 14th (right) and 17th (left) Streets.

February 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

About 1934.

folder: Union Square (East) & Between 15th and 17th Streets (East)., Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square East, north from East 15th (right) to 17th Streets, showing the crowds thronging the streets at this focal point during the May Day Parade. This is a set of 3 views, No. 2 of which shows a further view northward on Fourth Ave. (same as Union Square East when north of East 17th Street).

May 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
